Award.AwardTitle: NSF/FDA SIR: Multimodal characterization of quantitative biomarkers for traumatic brain injury measured via portable device technology

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
PI: Fisher, Jonathan
Proposal Number:1541612

This proposal, whose driving goal is the need for a portable device capable of quantifying biomarkers of traumatic brain injury (TBI), focuses on determining the utility of Electroencephalography (EEG) and Diffuse Correlation Spectrography (DCS) for detecting TBI biomarkers in an animal model.

TBI is a very significant issue in both military and civilian medicine. Diagnosis and assessment of TBI patients is generally performed using clinical imaging modalities (MRI, CT). However, the future availability of portable devices for assessing TBI would fundamentally improve the outlook for TBI patients. The diagnosis and treatment of TBI is impeded by gaps in regulatory science due to a lack of quantifiable biomarkers. Two complementary measurement parameters have potential to fill this gap. (1) measurement of somatosensory evoked electrophysiological potentials (SSEPs); and (2) diffuse correlation spectroscopy (DCS). This proposal seeks to evaluate the utility of these parameters for detecting TBI in an animal model without the need for a baseline, pre-injury measurement.

Performance_Institution.Name: U.S. Food and Drug Administration / CDRH

POR.DRECONTENT:
The work performed during the award period explored new optical and electrophysiological technology for detecting traumatic brain injury (TBI), a condition that leads to millions of hospitalizations and roughly 50,000 deaths each year in the U.S. alone.

Overall, we were successfully able to achieve all of the stated specific goals, which jointly aimed to explore how sensory evoked brain activity—changes in terms of both electrical activity and cerebral blood flow (CBF)—are changed by TBI. In terms of the impact of TBI on electrical activity, we demonstrated, in animals, that sensory evoked electroencephalographic (EEG) potentials can be utilized to detect and monitor acute brain injury (Fisher et al., IEEE Trans. Neural Sys. Rehab. 2016).

Because regional blood flow in the brain is dynamically coupled to activity in co-localized neurons, we explored the use of optical techniques, namely diffuse correlation spectroscopy (DCS), to explore sensory-activated hemodynamic biomarkers by performing continuous DCS measurements during somatosensory stimulation following controlled brain injury. Optical signals detected by DCS are particularly sensitive to CBF in microvasculature, which is intimately linked to regional electrical activation. We created 3D-printed miniaturized probes that permitted co-localized recordings of CBF and electrical activity in the brain region most sensitive to touch sensation in the limbs (somatosensory cortex). Similar to the effects in electrical activity, we found that injury also acutely reduces the amplitude of stimulus-evoked CBF. The amplitude of stimulus-evoked CBF appeared to recover to preinjury values more rapidly than the SSEP signal.

In total, our results suggest that combined measurements of somatosensory-evoked CBF and electrophysiological responses can jointly offer new quantitative metrics for brain injury. The work yielded a journal publication, another in preparation, and two published conference abstracts. In terms of the broader goal of increasing diversity of training settings for young scientists, the work further provided an opportunity for a postdoctoral scientist to perform research in a hybrid government/academic context.
